Guided by its strange connection to other frequencies, I traced my way through countless overlapping spaces until I found the remains of an Exostrider.
That was when I realized that Exostriders were built to transport Sentinels.
They trekked through stars to deliver Sentinels to Solaris. Until, during one jump, the Threnodian Aleph-1 must've noticed them.
Its hunger had festered for so long that not even devouring the entire universe could sate it now.
That frequency then led me to another relic consumed by the Threnodian—a creation built by the same makers of the Exostriders.
It was beyond my understanding. I could only guess its purpose: a communication satellite.
And within its ruined shell, I discovered frequencies tied to you.
You said you wanted to go home. Even if just to lay eyes on it, one more time.
They were the ones who cut communications! They ignored every wish you had outside your mission! They forced you into this life of roving!
And still, you... you...
You crossed the stars to fulfill their wish! How could they... HOW DARE THEY TREAT YOU LIKE THAT?!
In that moment, I was... drowning in pain.
I didn't know how to help you. I didn't know if I should tell you. I didn't know what future you'd even want.
That's when your frequency I'd been carrying with me... it was corrupted by the Voidmatter. It tore through my power, and Sigillum was born.
At first, it acted on nothing but the instinct to go home.
It craved your frequency, trying to make itself whole, trying to seize access to my piloting control…
…So it could reactivate the Exostrider and cross the Stridergate to get back home.
This is what I've been keeping from you... I'm sorry.
I'm glad you chose to tell me this, Aemeath.
But don't worry. The journey I've had since losing my memories, the hope I found... that's mine to keep. No one can take that.
"Saving the world"... I never saw it that way. The people and civilizations I met, they saved themselves. I was just there to help.
I'm no savior who fell from the sky. And no one ever saved themselves by waiting for one. There's been plenty I couldn't do. Losses I couldn't prevent. Sacrifices I had to accept.
But I'd do it all again. Every bit of it.
If this was a mission from my past, I'd be lying if I said I didn't care what they thought of me now. But that's a question for later. Right now, we have more important threats to face.
The fact that I'd choose this path even without my memories. That tells me this is who I am. I can't stand by while the Lament brings suffering. I care about this world too much.
But... I'm afraid you'll feel alone.
With everyone here? With you here? Not a chance.
I will be there for everyone... As we head toward our shared future, leaving the past behind.
So, this is <ano=my>your</ano> choice.
Is it worth it?
I'll decide the worth of this mission, not them.
The meaning of the path ahead is mine to decide.
I know where I'm going now. That's what matters, not where I started.
Then keep going.
No matter what.
The Core... it's returned to the Exostrider. It's one step closer to finally awakening.
And you? Your power should be restored now that Sigillum is gone.
It's more than restored. The Core's return has rebuilt my frequency from the ground up. I'm a full Exostrider Resonator now.
So will others be able to see you now?
That's right! Guess our little road trip movie's come to an end. Time to head back to Startorch Academy. Together!
My original body is still gone, of course. I'll always be a ghost in the machine. But my "existence" is now strong enough to be detected.
It's like a faint current turning into a bright, flickering spark!
Hearing this... it's a lot to process. I'd be lying if I said it wasn't.
I just need time to figure out my next move. This "homeland" of mine, even saying it feels strange to me.
From those fragments, I saw the messages you sent home. Not about your mission, but full of longing.
But their reply was... a rejection. Because it wasn't part of your mission. Because it was "unnecessary."
It was born from my mind. From all my worries, my fears, everything I imagined you'd suffered.
Exactly. The more of your frequency it consumed, the more coherent it became. I couldn't let you hear those words, so I... I tried to destroy it.

You stop Aemeath from giving Sigillum the killing blow and learn the truth about yourself: you are from beyond this world, sent on a long mission, but told by your homeland you could never return.
After learning this, you make peace with it. Aemeath's inner conflict is eased, and she cries in your embrace. The frequency Sigillum took from you merges back with your own.
The Reactor Core returns to the Exostrider, marking the end of your road trip. It is time to return to the Academy.
Jinzhou's soldiers fought through Retroact Rain till dawn.
The Black Shores Bloom Bearers ran themselves ragged across distant lands.
Rinascita's factions all dared to defy the Dark Tide.
Lahai-Roi's people never stopped reaching for the stars.
Now that your frequency is stable, what will you do next? Stay in Lahai-Roi, maybe?
The Threnodian here needs to be dealt with first.
Hah, of course. Typical workaholic. I knew you'd say that.
Aleph-1 won't be an easy fight. But I believe in you. You're the one who keeps making the impossible possible.
And after that, will you keep traveling? Any destination in mind?
I need to think about that.
Of course. Take your time.
This world you've chosen is vast. You can go anywhere.
Are you leaving now?
Yes. There's something I have to do.
The Academy will look after you. Or you can go back to live in Bjartr Woods.
When... when will you come back?
I don't know, Aemeath. I'm sorry.
But I'll come back to see you when I can. I promise.
You promise?
Promise.
Then, I'll wait for you here in Lahai-Roi.
Don't feel you have to. The world is vast. Don't let me or Lahai-Roi hold you back.
B-but, you can live for so, so many years. What if I'm gone by the time you return—
Sorry. I shouldn't have said that. You should go now.
Aemeath—
Just go!
I know you're worried.
It's not fair. Why does it have to be you saving the world? You're always so exhausted, always getting hurt.
Look, Aemeath...
I've walked through lands torn apart by the Lament. Every tear weighs me down, and every cry breaks a bit of my heart.
Their pain is no different from mine. Neither is their joy.
So if I can help, I will. I have to.
Then… I'll be the one to protect you someday.
You... protect me?
Yes! You're not invincible! You get hurt, you get tired, you get sad. You're just like everyone else in this world.
So I'll protect you.
I'll chase off anyone who tries to hurt you! Like Katya from Space Fantasy!
I'll become a savior, just like you.
Hehe...
Don't laugh! I'm serious!
Alright, alright, I'll stop now. I know you're serious. And I'm listening to every word.
I'll be counting on you then, Aemeath.
Tired?
The frequency Sigillum took is coming back. It's… not a great feeling. Abby's already helping me recover through the Tacet Mark. I'll be fine soon.
Just close your eyes and take a nap. You deserve a little peace.
(Close your eyes.)
You can count on me...

In the past, a young Aemeath worried about your departure from Lahai-Ro, but you explained to her the duty you felt to save the world from the Lament. She proudly patted her chest, promising to protect you. You playfully booped her nose and told her that you're counting on her.
In the present, with Sigillum's frequency now integrated back into you, you feel drowsy. After chatting with Aemeath for a while longer, you eventually fall asleep.
(Huh? Why am I in control of Sigillum?)
(Is it because… I absorbed its frequency?)
(Aemeath's mind space is even more chaotic than last time.)
Sigillum… Back for more? Thought I made a mess of you last time.
Hah… I can tear you apart a thousand times, but you never really die, do you? Fine. You're going to sit there and listen to me lose it!
After all, there's no one else to hear this.
(I can't speak… or move. Was Sigillum incapable of speech back then?)
You know, I found something interesting in the Exostrider's Reactor Drive.
A message left by my future self.
Years ago, while sailing the stars toward Solaris, an Exostrider caught the attention of Aleph-1.
Both of them tore through the Stridergate, clashing in the caverns deep below.
The Exostrider has combat features, but it was still no match for Aleph-1.
Its body was shattered, energy nearly depleted. And Voidmatter kept pouring through the Stridergate. Aleph-1 kept pushing, desperate to squeeze its whole disgusting bulk into this world.
It was almost successful. It would've ended everything.
But then a girl named Aemeath emerged from inside the Threnodian itself. The great savior, making her dramatic entrance at the final moment!
The Exostrider watched her touch its greatsword, the one pinning the Threnodian. Their resonance sent a surge of power back into the Reactor Drive.
It turned the massive blade, forcing the Threnodian back through the Stridergate and driving a seal over it.
But the human girl who had resonated with the Exostrider? She was dragged through the Stridergate with the Threnodian, vanishing from Solaris forever.
(Aemeath was the key? She helped the Exostrider seal the Threnodian?)
